crnrstn_element.crnrstn_description:
If one needs to check to see if the client IP is to be denied access before potentially returning a result or processing data, the denyIPAccess() method will evaluate the comma delimited string of IP/ranges provided and will return TRUE if the client IP matches the provided $ip.
Rather than hard coding IP directly into the denyIPAccess() method wherever it is applied throughout your application, it is recommended that a key such as "DENIED_ACCESS_IP" be defined through defineEnvResource() in the CRNRSTN Suite configuration file and that these IP restrictions then be managed from one place through edits to the config file for that key (see examples below).

crnrstn_techspecscontent.crnrstn_techspec: Currently tested on an Ubuntu Server 16.04 running PHP 7.0.22/MySQLi 5.0.12 and CentOS 7 Linux (a 100% compatible rebuild of the Red Hat Enterprise Linux) running PHP 5.6.32/MySQLi 5.5.58.
It is recommended that you upgrade to the latest official release of PHP to take advantage of gains in security and processing efficiency together with the latest features and functionality.

I still need to do testing with IPv6 address handling to confirm that CRNRSTN Suite performs as expected in that area. If you have the ability to test the IPv6 address handling of the CRNRSTN Suite and give feedback, it would be much appreciated.

crnrstn_parameter.crnrstn_paramdefinition:
The CRNRSTN Suite :: will process IP addresses provided in the following formats...e.g., as either an individual value or a comma delimited list:
'127.0.0.1'
'127.0.0.1, 127.*, 128.0.4.50, 128.0.4.60, 130.50.*, 130.51.10.*'
'192.168.*,172.16.100.1-172.16.120.1'
'FE80::210:80FF:FEF3:4605, 130.*,130.51.10.*,FE80::230:80FF:FEF3:4701'
'FE80::230:80FF:FEF3:4701'
